DOC.HEAD: Once-Booming Takeover Business Ends the Decade Quietly
Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, to CORRECT one less deal to two fewer deals.
DOC.TEXT: The once-raucous takeover business ended the 1980s subdued and humbled as the value of corporate acquisitions plunged more than 60 percent in the fourth quarter from the stratospheric levels of a year earlier. There were 935 acquisitions valued at $72.2 billion announced during the last quarter of 1989. A year earlier, when the merger business reached its zenith with the record $24.53 billion buyout of RJR Nabisco Inc., there were two fewer deals, 933, but the acquisitions totaled a record $183.1 billion. Leveraged buyouts, the debt-financed deals so popular a year ago, dropped even more sharply. There were 22 LBOs announced during the fourth quarter of 1989, totaling $15.5 billion _ down 85 percent from the 49 deals worth $102.2 billion in the last quarter of 1988. The figures, compiled by the financial research firm Securities Data Corp., were unsurprising. The takeover business has been devastated over the past year by the failure of Campeau Corp.'s $6.6 billion buyout of Federated Department Stores Inc. and the subsequent collapse of the market in junk bonds, the high-interest securities used to finance many buyouts. The enthusiasm that takeover strategists and their bankers once displayed was replaced by caution in 1989. Over the year, 1,447 purchases of U.S. businesses worth a total of $362.7 billion were announced, down 29 percent in value from the 1,543 acquisitions worth $511.5 billion in 1988. Securities Data considered transactions worth $10 million or more in compiling its figures. The 1989 record of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co., the company that bought RJR Nabisco, is an illustration of how times have changed. In 1988, Kohlberg Kravis, considered the leader among leveraged buyout firms, announced four transactions worth $27.88 billion. Excluding RJR Nabisco, the company's other deals totaled $3.35 billion. But in 1989, Kohlberg Kravis participated in one deal worth just $310 million, the buyout of several small divisions of Macmillan Inc. Kohlberg Kravis likely adopted the same cautious stance that other prospective acquirers have had to take. Ruth Pachman, a spokeswoman for the firm, declined to say that Kohlberg Kravis had become more conservative. However, she said, ``They're not going to do a deal for the sake of doing a deal.'' Kohlberg Kravis, although buoyed by the stellar performance of RJR Nabisco this year, has had to contend with financial problems at some of its smaller units that may have put a crimp into some of its acquisition plans. Earlier this week, Hillsborough Holdings Corp., formed as part of Kohlberg Kravis' takeover of homebuilder Jim Walter Corp., filed for federal bankruptcy court protection. Another Kohlberg Kravis company, Seaman Furniture Co. has been forced to reschedule its debt payments, and a third company, SCI Television Inc. also is trying to renegotiate its debt. The slowdown in takeovers also was evident in financing of deals and merchant banking activity, Securities Data said. There were 67 junk bond offerings raising a total of $14.1 billion in 1989, with $4 billion of that amount attributable to just one deal, the RJR Nabisco buyout. In 1988, there were 90 junk bond offerings that raised $16.4 billion, Securities Data said. Meanwhile, major investment banks participated directly in 82 deals worth $24.8 billion this past year. In 1988, there were 83 such transactions, but they totaled $95.5 billion, far outdistancing the 1989 total.
